instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: Hello guys , have an. <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that would not display. The machine powers up fine and chimes too , but no image. when I power up the machine , just before it chimes I get 5V on L8300 but drops to 0V.  <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>LCD_PDR_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> signals are all not present ... please help heys

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
"I get 5V on L8300 but drops to 0V"
Check if at same time <SIGNAL>LCD_HPD_CONN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> go high; with LCD connected, of course.
Try known good compatible LCD assembly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: The client had to discontinue the repair .
